name: K2-136
scenarioDescription:
The K2-136 Exoplanetary System


Overview

K2-136 is a star with 0.74 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.66 times its radius. It is located NaN light years away from the solar system.

K2-136 is known to have undefined exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the K2-136 system


K2-136 b

K2-136 b was discovered by the undefined observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is NaN astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of K2-136 b is 0.9380999999999999 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-136 b is 0.99 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, K2-136 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.


K2-136 c

K2-136 c was discovered by the undefined observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.12 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of K2-136 c is 8.8086 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-136 c is 2.91 that of Earth. At 8.8086 Earth masses, K2-136 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


K2-136 d

K2-136 d was discovered by the undefined observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is NaN astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of K2-136 d is 2.69982 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-136 d is 1.45 that of Earth. At 2.69982 Earth masses, K2-136 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system K2-136, which contains undefined planets and was discovered by undefined.
